text: Resistance to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells

The <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulatory pathway is crucial for effective antigen - specific T-cell cytokine production , and <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can directly suppress this response by inhibiting <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> tyrosine phosphorylation and binding of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase [ 24 ] .

To evaluate the responsiveness of RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , purified PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from three patients with active RA and from three healthy controls were stimulated by immobilized anti - <extra_id_0> CD3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody and anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody with or without diluted concentrations of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for 36 hours , and <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was measured by ELISA .

As shown in Fig . 1 , <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by activated normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells was mostly inhibited at concentrations as low as 1 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

However , RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells were able to produce significant amounts of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the presence of 1 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and the maximal but not complete inhibition by <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was obtained at 10-100 ng / ml .

We thus compared the levels of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells after <extra_id_0> CD3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulation in the presence of 1 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA patients with active disease ( multiple inflammatory joints , CRP level > / = 10 mg / l ) and inactive disease ( in remission , CRP level < 10 mg / l ) [ 26 ] and in healthy controls .

There were no statistically significant differences in <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production without <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> among these three groups ( Fig . 2a ) , but the inhibitory effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was significantly limited in the active RA group as compared with the inactive RA group and healthy controls ( percentage decrease : active RA , 2.9 +/- 14.4 % ; inactive RA , 45.6 +/- 14.4 % ; controls , 65.8 +/- 7.9 % ) ( Fig . 2b ) .

As a consequence , <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from active RA patients produced higher levels of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the presence of 1 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> than did normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells ( Fig . 2a ) .

In addition , we compared <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells after CD3 and <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulation in the presence of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in active RA patients and in healthy controls .

Similarly , <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was not affected by 1 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA patients ( percentage decrease , -2.1 +/- 13.8 % ) , while it was significantly reduced in healthy controls ( 61.1 +/- 13.7 % ; P < 0.05 ) .

Taken together , these results indicate that RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells become less susceptible to the immunoregulatory effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> during the active phase .
